title: Fountain - Brookman Building
description: This fountain is outside the University of SA Brookman Building.

title: Fountain - Art Gallery of South Australia
description: The Art Gallery of South Australia is one of several major cultural institutions that line North Terace between Kintore Avenue and Frome Road.

title: 14 Pieces Fountain - South Australian Museum
description: 14 Pieces is a sculpture fountain based on the opalised fossilised vertebrae of the Ichthyosaur in the South Australian Museum.

title: Bill's Fountain - State Library of South Australia
description: This fountain is a memorial to William Faulding Scammell, AO, CBE who was Chancellor of Adelaide University from 1991 to 1998.

title: War Memorial Fountain
description: South Australia became the first state in Australia to build a memorial for the First World War.

title: Susan Grace Benny Plaque
description: The first female local government councillor in Australia, Benny was a Justice of the Peace, a businesswoman and a lobbyist for women’s equality.

title: Fish for the Slate Pool Walkway
description: Within Catherine Truman’s work, Fish for the Slate Pool Walkway, the tentative nature of life is captured brilliantly from the depths of Truman’s imagination.

title: Robinson Bridge
description: Robinson’s swing bridge opened at Dock 1 in October 1886.

title: Torrens Lake Fountain
description: The Torrens Lake Fountain commemorates the first time South Australia was visited by a reigning monarch, Queen Elizabeth II in 1954.

title: J Reedman Memorial Drinking Fountain
description: The J Reedman Memorial Drinking Fountain was erected in Creswell Gardens on 7 September 1929. It is made of Angaston marble and signifies the achievements of John Cole Reedman, an Australian sports legend.

title: Farnese Hercules
description: One of three statues given to Adelaide by WA Horn, Hercules was unveiled in October 1892 in Victoria Square.

title: Sir Ross Smith Memorial
description: The Sir Ross Smith Memorial commemorates the achievements of aviator Sir Ross Smith and the first flight from England to Australia.

title: JH & GF Angas Memorial
description: The Angas Memorial was completed in 1915 as a tribute to the memory of George Fife Angas and John Howard Angas, colonists who contributed to the foundation of South Australia.

title: Bent Street Mural
description: Tony Rosella and Ash Rundle's environmentally and historically inspired artwork on the South Australian Police Building on Grenfell Street.

title: 'Street Art Poetry Project' Location 3
description: Mark Niehus' four-part series cemented his status as a prominent poet and artist in Adelaide.

title: A Day Out
description: Pigs and people in Rundle Mall

title: Owen Broughton Sculpture
description: This Owen Broughton work won the 1976 Rundle Mall sculpture contest alongside Bert Flugelman's Mall's Balls

title: 'The Apron' by Karen Genoff
description: The Minister for Housing & Urban Development commissionned this work by Karen Genoff, an Adelaide local.

title: Mike Maka Mural
description: Mike Maka’s mural features a tired rhinocerous carrying the city of Adelaide on its back.

title: Rundle Lantern
description: The Rundle Lantern is 100% green-powered and the light show is carbon neutral.

title: J150 Plaque, Joachim Matthias Wendt
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Mary Jane Warnes
description: Deeply affected by the isolation and loneliness of her early married life, Mary Jane Warnes strived to improve conditions for her fellow countrywomen by founding the South Australian Country Women’s Association.

title: J150 Plaque, Norman Tindale
description: Norman Tindale was a prodigious anthropologist and polymath who chronicled Aboriginal culture, studied butterflies and moths, and broke Japanese wartime codes.

title: J150 Plaque, 'Padre' Arthur Thomas Strange
description: Kind-hearted and single-minded, 'Padre' Arthur Strange was the founder of the Helping Hand Centre.

title: J150 Plaque, David Shearer
description: Though a manufacturer of agricultural machinery, David Shearer also designed an early car, constructed an observatory, and was a keen artist.

title: J150 Plaque, Ronald Max'y Sharpe
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, James Arthur Prescott
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Eldred Norman
description: A racing car designer and driver, Eldred Norman was interested in all things mechanical.

title: J150 Plaque, William Muirden
description: William Muirden founded the Muirden College for Business Training, and was known for his well-balanced and harmonious nature.

title: J150 Plaque, Peter Nelson and Marjorie Jackson Nelson
description: A resolute cyclist, Peter Nelson was married to Marjorie Jackson Nelson and died of leukaemia at a young age. A phenomenally successful athlete in her own right, Marjorie Jackson Nelson went on to become a governor of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, May Mills
description: Educationist and sports administrator May Mills believed 'the wholesome development of a nation' depended on sport.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir John Melrose
description: Despite going blind, pastoralist and philanthropist Sir John Melrose continued to work with stock and managed properties.

title: J150 Plaque, John Abel McPherson
description: A union official and social reformer who was not a socialist, John McPherson became the first leader of South Australia's Parliamentary Labor Party.

title: J150 Plaque, Murdoch Stanley McLeod
description: A very industrious and conservative businessman, Murdoch McLeod was generous but modest and never flamboyant.

title: J150 Plaque, Percy Raymond Begg
description: Literally born in a tent, Percy Begg became a pioneer orthodontist whose innovations benefit patients to this day.

title: J150 Plaque, Dame Ruby Litchfield
description: Befitting a dedicated community worker and charity organizer, Dame Ruby Litchfield’s simple philosophy was ‘To live and let live’.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir William Mitchell
description: Philosopher, Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, and a teacher of economics, psychology and literature, Sir William Mitchell was nothing if not a polymath.

title: Birkenhead Bridge
description: Opened in 1940 as a replacement for the original Jervois Bridge, the Birkenhead Bridge was the first to employ a double-bascule design in Australia, and continues to function as a critical link between Port Adelaide and Lefevre Peninsula.

title: Jervois Bridge
description: For over half a century Port Adelaide’s Jervois Bridge was the only link by which pedestrians and wheeled vehicles could transit between the Port and Lefevre Peninsula.

title: J150 Plaque, Julian Edmund Tenison Woods
description: Julian Woods was the co-founder of the Sisters of St. Joseph, and a creative priest, educationist and scientist.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Kenneth Wills
description: Businessman and soldier Sir Kenneth Wills was Controller of the Allied Intelligence Bureau during the Second World War.

title: J150 Plaque, Lawrence Allen Wells
description: Explorer and surveyor Lawrence Wells survived gruelling expeditions but died after being struck by a railcar.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Samuel Way
description: A Chief Justice of South Australia, Sir Samuel Way was polished, cultured and proud.

title: J150 Plaque, Adelaide Laetitia Miethke
description: Prussian by descent, Adelaide Miethke was an educationist, and her School of the Air ‘bridged the lonely distance’ for outback children.

title: J150 Plaque, George Elton Mayo
description: George Elton Mayo was an extraordinarily versatile pioneer in human relations, management studies and psychoanalysis.

title: J150 Plaque, Cecil Thomas Madigan
description: A geologist and explorer, Cecil Madigan crossed the Simpson Desert in the last classic Australian exploration adventure.

title: J150 Plaque, Peter Waite
description: A pastoralist who built an empire on sheep and cattle runs, Peter Waite was also a major philanthropist.

title: J150 Plaque, William Charles Douglas Veale
description: Soldier, engineer and Adelaide Town Clerk William Veale is celebrated for revitalising the city's parklands.

title: J150 Plaque, David Unaipon
description: David Unaipon was an Aboriginal leader, writer, gatherer of legends, and inventor who was referred to in the press as 'the Black Leonardo'.

title: J150 Plaque, Alfred Hermann Traeger
description: Alf Traeger was friendly but self-effacing, and is perhaps best known as the inventor of the pedal wireless.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Robert Richard Torrens
description: Land titles reformer Sir Robert Richard Torrens reformed, amended and even radicalised the land trade system.

title: J150 Plaque, Alexander Tolmer
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Doris Taylor
description: Doris Taylor was the founder and organizer of Meals on Wheels, despite spending most of her life in a wheelchair.

title: J150 Plaque, Thomas Quinton Stow
description: Founder of the Congregational Church in South Australia, Thomas Stow was a strenuous minister and a dedicated opponent of state aid to religion.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edward Stirling
description: Sir Edward Stirling was (among other things) a surgeon, scientist, educationist, curator, lecturer and parliamentarian; in short, a Renaissance Man.

title: J150 Plaque, Tom Elder Barr Smith
description: A proverbial chip off the old block, Tom Elder Barr Smith was an astute businessman and generous philanthropist.

title: J150 Plaque, Robert Barr Smith
description: Robert Barr Smith had a genius for business. He was also a generous philanthropist, though his modesty dictated that much of the funding was dispensed anonymously.

title: J150 Plaque, Richard Bowyer Smith
description: Richard Bowyer Smith and his brother Clarence could both rightfully claim distinction as the inventors of the stump-jump plough.

title: J150 Plaque, Alfred Muller Simpson
description: Not content with being the nation’s biggest metal goods manufacturer, Alfred Muller Simpson was prominent in public life too.

title: J150 Plaque, Augustus Short
description: The energetic Augustus Short, South Australia’s first Anglican bishop, laid firm foundations for the growth of the Anglican Church in the new colony.

title: J150 Plaque, Richard Moritz Schomburgk
description: A botanist, horticulturist and the director of the Adelaide Botanic Garden, Richard Schomburgk was honoured locally as 'the people’s pet'.

title: J150 Plaque, Luther Robert Scammell
description: Manufacturing chemist Luther Scammell prepared compounds, saved a struggling business, and coined the name ‘Solyptol’.

title: J150 Plaque, John Ridley
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Victor York Richardson
description: The term 'all-round sportsman' might have been coined for Victor York Richardson, who excelled at cricket, football, baseball, lacrosse, tennis and basketball.

title: J150 Plaque, Arnold Edwin Victor Richardson
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, William Richard Randell
description: William Randell was a pioneer of River Murray paddle-steamers, and was responsible for both designing and piloting them.

title: J150 Plaque, Alexander Maurice Ramsay
description: As general manager of the South Australian Housing Trust, Alexander Maurice Ramsay was energetic and compassionate.

title: J150 Plaque, Tom Price
description: As the first Labor premier of South Australia, Tom Price established a minimum wage and electrified the tramways.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Archibald Grenfell Price
description: Working with this vivacious geographer, historian and educationist was said to be ‘like hanging on the tail of a comet’.

title: J150 Plaque, Margaret Preston
description: A highly influential painter and printmaker, Margaret Preston was once described as ‘a natural enemy of the dull’.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Thomas Playford
description: Premier for 26 years, Sir Thomas Playford managed the industrialisation of South Australia while maintaining a conservative social agenda.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Mark Oliphant
description: Best known as a governor of South Australia, Sir Mark Oliphant was also a pioneering nuclear physicist who became an outspoken anti-nuclear campaigner.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Henry Newland
description: Sir Henry Newland gained an international reputation as a pioneer plastic surgeon.

title: J150 Plaque, Paris Nesbit
description: Barrister, intellectual and proud hedonist, Paris Nesbit was an early starter who allegedly read Milton at three and translated Goethe at ten.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Mellis Napier
description: Sir Mellis Napier was a Chief Justice of South Australia, and arguably a reactionary one.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Pearcy Mountford
description: Charles Mountford was an anthropologist, writer and photographer, and was dedicated to the promotion of Aboriginal art and mythology.

title: J150 Plaque, William Mortlock
description: William Mortlock was a pastoralist and a generous and popular, if not necessarily brilliant, parliamentarian.

title: J150 Plaque, Daniel Moriarty
description: Daniel Moriarty has been acclaimed as the greatest footballer between the two World Wars.

title: J150 Plaque, Dame Roma Mitchell
description: A trailblazing jurist, Dame Roma Mitchell pushed for numerous law reforms and became South Australia’s first female governor.

title: A Day Out
description: Pigs and people in Rundle Mall

title: J150 Plaque, Helen Mary Mayo
description: Medical practitioner Helen Mayo combined energy and a strong social conscience in her promotion of child health services.

title: J150 Plaque, Frederick May
description: Frederick May was an engineer and manufacturer, and the archetypal 'quiet achiever' who missed out on major fame and success.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Douglas Mawson
description: Sir Douglas Mawson became famous as an Antarctic explorer, but the geology of South Australia was his life’s work.

title: J150 Plaque, James Martin
description: A man of many parts, James Martin was an inventor, politician, philanthropist, engineer and ‘The Father of Gawler’.

title: J150 Plaque, Mary Helen MacKillop
description: An educationist and co-founder of the Sisters of St. Joseph, Mary MacKillop is now famous as Australia’s only Catholic saint.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edward Hayward
description: Known as ‘Bill’, Sir Edward Hayward was a businessman, patron of the arts and the originator of the Adelaide Christmas pageant.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Walter Crocker
description: A true internationalist, Sir Walter Crocker was a diplomat and Australian ambassador to many countries, a writer, and a centenarian.

title: J150 Plaque, Kate Cocks
description: Kate Cocks was both a welfare worker and the first woman police constable in the British Empire.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir John Cleland
description: Pathologist, naturalist and ardent conservationist, Professor Cleland, as he preferred to be known, contributed across many fields.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Robert Chapman
description: Sir Robert Chapman was an engineer with a gift for recognising the fundamentals of any problem.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Witto-Witto Cawthorne
description: Cawthorne was a dynamic music seller and concert manager, and is remembered as a genial raconteur.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Hugh Cairns
description: A pioneering neurosurgeon, Cairns worked extensively in the field of head injuries and was one of the first to promote the use of crash helmets for motor cyclists.

title: J150 Plaque, Henry John 'Harry' Butler
description: Harry Butler was a charismatic young aviator with a barnstorming style.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir George Brookman
description: A wealthy businessman and quiet philanthropist, Sir George Brookman was a conservative who was described as ‘hard but fair’ by one of his descendants.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Langdon Bonython
description: Sir Langdon Bonython was a progressive liberal whose long life encompassed being a parliamentarian, newspaper proprietor and philanthropist.

title: J150 Plaque,Lady Jean Bonython
description: Lady Bonython grew from ‘Baby Mayoress’ into a community worker and supporter of numerous charities, especially those benefiting women and children.

title: J150 Plaque, Abraham Tobias Boas
description: Abraham Tobias Boas was the first rabbi in South Australia, but so inclusive he was also called ‘the best Christian in Adelaide’.

title: J150 Plaque, John McConnell Black
description: Remembered as an eminent botanist, Black was also an accomplished linguist, who reprimanded his grandchildren in French and his dog in Spanish.

title: J150 Plaque, John Bishop
description: Instigator and first Artistic Director of the Adelaide Festival, John Bishop was a musician, teacher and visionary.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Richard Baker
description: An influential conservative politician and a supporter of Federation, Sir Richard Baker was the first President of the Senate.

title: J150 Plaque, John Stokes Bagshaw
description: ‘If worth doing, do it well’ was the motto of John Bagshaw, pioneering designer and manufacturer of agricultural machinery.

title: J150 Plaque, Walter Hervey Bagot
description: Bagot was an architect whose work, including Bonython Hall and the Barr Smith Library, displays his preference for classical and traditional designs.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Henry Ayers
description: A businessman, banker and parliamentarian, Henry Ayers was astute, hard-headed and politically adroit.

title: J150 Plaque, George French Angas
description: Equal parts naturalist and artist, George French Angas depicted the South Australian landscape, Aboriginal inhabitants, and flora and fauna with meticulous accuracy.

title: J150 Plaque, George Fife Angas
description: This merchant, banker, landowner and philanthropist was generous but shrewd, and often tagged with the phrase ‘philanthropy plus ten per cent’.

title: Dame Roma Mitchell Statue
description: Dame Roma Mitchell is depicted surrounded by her books looking relaxed and at home on North Terrace.

title: Pioneer Women's Memorial
description: The Pioneer Women's Memorial in the Garden of Remembrance is a tribute to the pioneer women of South Australia.

title: Port Adelaide Lighthouse
description: Installed in the 1860s as Port Adelaide's first fixed navigational beacon, and later used at South Neptune Island, the Port Adelaide Lighthouse today functions as an iconic museum display in the heart of the Port.

title: Steam Tug Yelta
description: Once an integral component of Port Adelaide's fleet of working vessels, this sole-surviving example of an operational South Australian steam tug has been faithfully restored and now promotes the Port's maritime heritage

title: Cross of Sacrifice
description: The Cross of Sacrifice, part of the Women's War Memorial, was funded completely by donation from 'the women of South Australia'

title: Archie Badenoch
description: Not many historic vessels in the care of maritime museums around the world still work as hard as South Australia’s ex-police launch, Archie Badenoch.

title: Barque South Australian
description: A former mail transport and Royal Navy vessel, the barque South Australian was integral to the early colonisation of South Australia...and became the colony's first documented shipwreck.

title: Sir Mark Oliphant bust
description: The bust of Sir Mark Oliphant on North Terrace honours an eminent scientist and the state’s first South Australian-born governor.

title: John Jefferson Bray Memorial Fountain
description: The John Jefferson Bray Memorial Fountain commemorates the life of a senior judge, scholar and poet

title: Sir Lawrence Bragg bust
description: The bust of Sir Lawrence Bragg commemorates a South Australian Nobel Laureate

title: Simpson and his Donkey
description: The iconic figure of of 'Simpson and his Donkey' looks over War Memorial Drive from the Angas Garden.

title: HMCS Protector
description: Built between 1882 and 1884, South Australia's only colonial warship was a veteran of three major conflicts and still exists today as a breakwater at Heron Island on the Great Barrier Reef

title: J150 Plaque, Harold Eustace Hill Ling
description: Harold Eustace Hill Ling was a joint patent-holder of that indisputable Australian icon, the Hills Hoist, and was responsible for expanding and diversifying Hills Industries Limited.

title: J150 Plaque, Essington Lewis
description: Essington Lewis was a hard-working industrialist who substantially developed and expanded B.H.P., and was Director-General of Munitions during the Second World War.

title: J150 Plaque, Andrew Alexander Kirkpatrick
description: A union leader, parliamentarian and egalitarian, Andrew Alexander Kirkpatrick pushed for equal rights for women.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Sidney Kidman
description: Abstemious but easy-going, Sir Sidney Kidman was a pastoralist and philanthropist who made friends easily.

title: J150 Plaque, August Kavel
description: An austere but tolerant Lutheran migrant leader, August Kavel contributed significantly to South Australia’s rich legacy of German culture.

title: J150 Plaque, Hooper Josse Brewster Jones
description: The music of unconventional musician and composer Hooper Josse Brewster Jones was as distinctive as his name.

title: J150 Plaque, Norman William Jolly
description: A forestry scientist by profession, Norman Jolly was also an accomplished scholar known for his integrity and keen critical faculty.

title: J150 Plaque, Jimmy James
description: A masterly Aboriginal police tracker, Jimmy James saved lives, gathered evidence and attained legendary status.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Roland Jacobs
description: Sir Roland Jacobs was a shrewd businessman, but also a warm and generous philanthropist with no interest in personal wealth.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Walter Watson Hughes
description: A pastoralist and mine-owner once accused of fraud, Hughes stated shortly before his death: ‘I have been a sinner all my life’.

title: J150 Plaque, Amos William Howard
description: Howard was a nurseryman and great promoter of subterranean clover. His discoveries have benefited farmers’ pastures throughout South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edward Holden
description: Motor car manufacturer and industrialist Sir Edward Holden gave his name to a car, albeit posthumously.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Hans Heysen
description: Sir Hans Heysen was a masterly artist, the immortaliser of the gum tree on canvas, and a dedicated conservationist.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Robert Helpmann
description: His versatility as actor, dancer, producer and choreographer, coupled with flamboyance and wit, made Sir Robert Helpmann a household name.

title: J150 Plaque, Colin Sidney Hayes
description: Colin Sidney Hayes is remembered as possibly the greatest racehorse trainer and thoroughbred breeder in the history of Australian racing.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Allan Seymour Hawker
description: Horribly wounded twice in World War One, the tenacious Hawker went on to be a pastoralist and parliamentarian.

title: J150 Plaque, George Frederick Hassell
description: A printer and publisher, George Frederick Hassell was devoted to the immaculate ’embellishment of books’.

title: J150 Plaque, John Anderson Hartley
description: Though stern and strict, educationist (and first Inspector-General of Schools) John Anderson Hartley favoured progressive and innovative ideas.

title: J150 Plaque, George Hannaford
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Alfred Hannaford
description: A manufacturer of agricultural machinery, Alfred Hannaford was also an inventor who devised a pickling machine.

title: J150 Plaque, 'Captain' Henry Richard Hancock
description: Imposing mine Superintendent Henry Richard Hancock substantially reorganized and developed the “Monster Mine” at Moonta.

title: J150 Plaque, George Hall
description: In the days before Coca-Cola and Pepsi, George Hall was a forward-thinking manufacturer of soft drinks.

title: J150 Plaque, Margaret Graham
description: Margaret Graham was an outspoken and forthright nursing sister and army matron, with a strong sense of justice.

title: J150 Plaque, George Woodroffe Goyder
description: A surveyor and conservationist, and incredibly prolific letter-writer, Goyder is mainly remembered for his famous ‘line of rainfall’.

title: J150 Plaque, William Christie Gosse
description: Short-lived explorer and surveyor William Christie Gosse was the first European to set eyes on Uluru.

title: J150 Plaque, Walter Gill
description: A conscientious and gifted forestry administrator, Walter Gill was also an enthusiastic nature photographer.

title: J150 Plaque, William Anstey Giles
description: Surgeon William Anstey Giles came from pioneering stock, but was a pioneer himself in medical literature.

title: J150 Plaque, Gladys Ruth Gibson
description: Gladys Ruth Gibson was an educationist and president of the National Council of Women – and by all accounts a loyal friend and loving family member.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Claude Gibb
description: An irascible yet open-minded engineer, industrialist and ideas man, Sir Claude Gibb was responsible for the design of the Centurion tank.

title: J150 Plaque, Alfred Edward Gerard
description: Electrical merchant Alfred Edward Gerard was also a concerned humanitarian, and a worker for Aboriginal welfare.

title: J150 Plaque, John Flynn
description: Founder of the Australian Inland Mission and Royal Flying Doctor Service, Flynn was a practical and restless innovator.

title: J150 Plaque, Lord Florey
description: Hundreds of millions of people have lived longer and healthier lives, thanks to medical scientist, Nobel Prize winner and penicillin pioneer Lord Florey.

title: J150 Plaque, Francis Hardy Faulding
description: Faulding was a manufacturing chemist, prominent businessman, city councillor and church benefactor.

title: J150 Plaque, Julia and George Farr
description: A clergyman and headmaster, George Henry Farr was a champion of gentlemanly behaviour, honesty and good sportsmanship. The plight of the girls in the Destitute Asylum spurred on his social worker wife, Julia Warren Farr.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Lloyd Dumas
description: At the end of his long life, newspaperman Sir Lloyd Dumas described himself as simply ‘the luckiest man in the world’.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Duguid
description: A medical practitioner, Charles Duguid was also a champion of the underdog who spent many of his 102 years as a worker for Aboriginal advancement.

title: J150 Plaque, C.J. Dennis
description: Dennis was a poet, journalist and satirist, renowned for The Songs of a Sentimental Bloke, the bestselling book of Australian poetry.

title: J150 Plaque, Lillian Daphne de Lissa
description: Hard working, widely read and exceptionally charming, Lillian Daphne de Lissa was an exotically named intellectual and kindergarten pioneer.

title: J150 Plaque, Peter Smith Dawson
description: A singer of both bush ballads and classics, Dawson was the first to record ‘Waltzing Matilda’.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Samuel Davenport
description: Davenport was a liberal-minded and literate parliamentarian and a promoter of industry, especially in the fields of horticulture and viniculture.

title: J150 Plaque, Constance Muriel Davey
description: Though hampered by a physical disability, Davey became a psychologist and educationist who worked untiringly for social justice.

title: J150 Plaque, David Dallwitz
description: Musician and artist with a wide range both sonically and visually.

title: The Immigrants
description: The Immigrants sculpture has been climbed on, sat on, stood next to and embraced by many people who have walked through the gates of the Migration Museum since 2006.

title: J150 Plaque, Catherine Helen Spence
description: Writer and social reformer Catherine Helen Spence was also the first woman to write a novel about Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Alexandrine Seager
description: A tireless worker for the welfare of soldiers, Alexandrine Seager founded and ran the Cheer-Up Society.

title: J150 Plaque, William Light
description: Remembered as the founder of the City of Adelaide, Light was South Australia’s first surveyor-general.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Kingston
description: Though dogged by scandal, Charles Kingston was a lawyer, parliamentarian and Federalist who steered many reforms through the South Australian Parliament and helped draft Australia’s Constitution.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir George Kingston
description: By turns architect, engineer, surveyor and parliamentarian, Sir George Kingston was also Speaker of the House of Assembly for almost two decades.

title: J150 Plaque, Samuel Thomas Gill
description: Artist Samuel Thomas Gill produced a lively visual record of early South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Edmund Wright
description: Some of Adelaide’s finest nineteenth-century buildings were designed by Edmund William Wright.

title: J150 Plaque, David Fowler
description: Merchant David Fowler built a successful grocery business, famous for jams, confectionery and preserved fruit.

title: J150 Plaque, Gladys Elphick
description: Known to all as ‘Aunty Glad’, Elphick was a tireless worker for Aboriginal welfare.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Thomas Elder
description: A pastoralist, philanthropist and businessman, Elder supported numerous outback expeditions and Adelaide institutions.

title: J150 Plaque, Don Dunstan
description: As premier, Dunstan’s agenda of social and political reform transformed South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Sturt
description: A soldier and explorer, Captain Charles Sturt was first to chart the River Murray.

title: J150 Plaque, John McDouall Stuart
description: Explorer and surveyor John McDouall Stuart was celebrated as a hero for leading the first European expedition to cross Australia from south to north.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edwin Thomas Smith
description: Sir Edwin Thomas Smith was a brewer, parliamentarian and, thanks to his philanthropy, Adelaide’s favourite millionaire.

title: J150 Plaque, Bejah Dervish
description: Camel driver Bejah Dervish, highly-regarded for his part in the Calvert Scientific Exploring Expedition in 1896, became a familiar figure in South Australia’s far north.

title: J150 Plaque, Mary Lee
description: Suffragist and social reformer Mary Lee was jubilant when, in 1894, South Australia became the first Australian colony to grant women the vote.

title: Aboriginal flag
description: The Aboriginal flag flies high over its birthplace, Tarntanyangga/Victoria Square, a symbol of Aboriginal pride, rights and identity.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Charles Todd
description: Sir Charles Todd was a leader in the fields of meteorology, astronomy and communications, and is best remembered for masterminding the construction of the Overland Telegraph Line.

title: Popeye
description: 'Popeye the Sailor' was a popular cartoon at the cinema in the 1930s when Gordon Watts introduced a tourist pleasure craft on the River Torrens

title: Sir Samuel Way Memorial Statue
description: A statue of Sir Samuel Way reflects his towering presence in legal, political and cultural circles in the last decades of the nineteenth century.

title: Queen Victoria Monument
description: Since 1894 Queen Victoria has looked imperiously over the bustle of Victoria Square

title: Robert Burns Memorial
description: One of many around the world, this statue of Scottish poet Robert Burns was unveiled in 1894

title: Matthew Flinders Memorial
description: A statue to honour Matthew Flinders, the first explorer to circumnavigate Australia, was a long time coming in Adelaide

title: Light Horse Memorial
description: Remembering South Australian Light Horsemen who served in Egypt and Palestine and at Gallipoli

title: Lavington Bonython fountain
description: Affectionately known as the ‘Bonython bath’, this fountain stood outside the South Australian Museum from 1965 to 2005

title: War Horse Memorial
description: Remembering the role of horses in war.

title: Lord Florey bust
description: Adelaide-born Lord Florey won the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1945 for his part in making the infection-fighting penicillin available

title: Knot
description: The shining steel and simple form of Knot typifies the work of sculptor Herbert (Bert) Flugelman.

title: Mary Lee bust
description: ‘My aim is to leave the world better for women’ – Mary Lee was an activist, suffragist and unionist

title: King Edward VII Memorial
description: Creating and installing King Edward VII’s statute took eight months longer than the period of his reign

title: Jubilee 150 Plaques
description: An eclectic selection of significant contributors to South Australia to 1986

title: John McDouall Stuart statue
description: The statue of inland explorer John McDouall Stuart at the corner of Victoria Square and Flinders Street, Adelaide, commemorates his place in Australian history

title: South African War Memorial
description: The mounted trooper reining in his horse commemorates South Australians who served in the South African War (1899-1902).

title: Sir Mellis Napier bust
description: The bronze bust of Sir Mellis Napier, sculpted by eminent South Australian artist John Dowie, commemorates his distinguished community service, including to the law and legal profession in South Australia

title: Spheres
description: Balancing and still among the bustle of Rundle Mall, Spheres is among Adelaide's favourite public artworks

title: The Slide
description: What fun! John Dowie’s work invigorates Rundle Mall

title: Venere di Canova
description: A startled Venus caused consternation as Adelaide’s first public statue in 1892

title: Elder Park Rotunda
description: Celebrated at its opening in 1882, and again a century later, the rotunda remains a focus point for events in Elder Park.

title: Dr John Dowie AM bust
description: Different, but a good likeness

title: Dardanelles Memorial
description: The first Anzac memorial - an obelisk in a grove of wattles

title: Colonel Light statue
description: Colonel William Light’s statue on Montefiore Hill pointing towards the centre of Adelaide has come to symbolise the city that Light laid out.

title: August Wilhelm Pelzer Plaque
description: A plaque to the 'City Gardener' is now obscured in a city garden

title: Colonel William Light Grave and Monument
description: Colonel William Light’s grave remains in Light Square, while Light's Monument there has been replaced and embellished over time

title: Colonel Light Survey Marker
description: Colonel William Light’s survey marker from 1837 is to be incorporated in the new Royal Adelaide Hospital site

title: Charles Cameron Kingston Memorial
description: A remarkable and feisty South Australian attorney-general and premier, a father of federation and the first Australian Minster for Trade and Customs is commemorated by this statue

title: Alice
description: Who, or what, is following Alice in Rymill Park?

title: Sir Douglas Mawson bust
description: The spirit of Antarctic explorer and professor of geology, Sir Douglas Mawson, is captured in the bust by John Dowie

title: Sir Thomas Elder statue
description: The sculpture of Elder is at the University of Adelaide, a major beneficiary of his philanthropy

title: Three Rivers Fountain
description: The Three Rivers fountain in Victoria Square commemorates the Royal Visit in 1963

title: Victor Richardson Gates
description: An outstanding all-round sportsman was provided with the rare honour of being memorialised during his lifetime

title: The Eternal Question
description: Word artist Richard Tipping prompts us to consider big ideas in his sculpture ‘The Eternal Question’

title: Sir Walter Watson Hughes statue
description: The bronze figure of Sir Walter Watson Hughes by Francis Williamson stands on a massive block of red granite.

title: Voyagers
description: The lives and cultures of ‘Afghan’ cameleers are recognised in Whitmore Square

title: War Memorial
description: Architect Louis Laybourne-Smith and sculptor George Rayner Hoff created a memorial that conveys the impact of the First World War

title: 14 Pieces
description: Recalling the ancient Ichthyosaur, this sculpture invites interaction

title: Captain Charles Sturt Memorial
description: Leaning forward and shielding his eyes from the sun, this bronze figure of Sturt looks over Victoria Square, not the land he explored

title: Catherine Helen Spence statue
description: The powerful sculpture of Catherine Helen Spence in Light Square, Adelaide celebrates the life and work of a formidable South Australian.

title: Beehive Corner
description: Built in 1896, Beehive Corner with its Neo-Gothic facade has been a famous meeting spot since the early 20th century.

title: Goodman Crescent - University of Adelaide
description: The University of Adelaide is a commanding presence on North Terrace. It began in 1874 when South Australia was less than 40 years old, with a population of about 200,000 people.

title: Torrens Building
description: Built in 1881, this heritage-listed building on Victoria Square has long captured the public's imagination with tales of secret tunnels.

title: Elder House
description: Elder House was built for Elder Smith and Co, and still bears the name though the company has merged with other businesses, evolved, and relocated.

title: Union Church, Peterborough
description: Union Chapel was the first building for many denominations in Peterborough.

title: The Space Between
description: Simple stone stands as a reminder of a painful past history.

title: Victoria Square/ Tarntanyangga
description: Victoria Square, named after Princess Victoria (later Queen Victoria) in 1836, is the central and most significant of Adelaide’s squares.

title: Hurtle Square / Tangkaira
description: Located in the south-east of Adelaide on the Kaurna peoples land of Tandayangga (place of the Red Kangaroo Dreaming), Hurtle Square was one of the six squares designed by Colonel William Light in his 1837 plan of Adelaide. The Square has since seen numerous planting schemes and re-designs that have altered both its appearance and layout.

title: West Terrace Cemetery
description: West Terrace Cemetery reflects the early population groups of Adelaide, and is a popular destination for tour groups.

title: Waterside Workers Hall
description: November 1960, 1,100 wharfies, tally clerks, seamen and their families cramed into the Waterside Workers Hall.

title: Prince Alfred Sailors Home
description: The first formal accommodation in Port Adelaide for visiting sailors was the Prince Alfred Sailors’ Home.

title: English and Australian Copper Company
description: The first copper smelter, Adelaide Smelting Company, was built at the Port in 1849.

title: Light Square/ Wauwi
description: Originally intended as a recreational garden oasis from the surrounding city, Light Square, however, developed a reputation for prostitution, drinking and violence.

title: Australian Imperial Forces (AIF) Cemetery
description: The cemetery was established following protests in February 1920 against the State Government from the League of Loyal Women, who campaigned against the treatment of over 150 returned soldiers buried in unmarked graves at West Terrace Cemetery. Exclusively for the burial of ex-service personnel, it was the first dedicated military cemetery in Australia.

title: Port Adelaide Customs House
description: Construction of Port Adelaide’s fourth customs house commenced in 1878, following demolition of the timber customs ho

title: St Vincent Street
description: Ozone is the first in a chain of three theatres established by a consortium of local small businessmen.

title: Iron Stores, Nile Street
description: Known as the Iron Stores, the semicircular warehouses were the first waterfront warehouses in the colony.

title: Electric Light Company
description: The Electric Light and Motive Power Company was the first to electrify street lights in South Australia.

title: Commercial Road
description: In 1839 Governor Gawler agreed to enter a joint venture with the South Australian Company relocating Port Adelaide from the end of what is now "Old Port Road" to the present site, marked by the SA maritime Museum's Lighthouse. Commercial Road was built over sandy and swampy ground, joining Port Road at Alberton.

title: Elder, Smith and Co’s Bonded and Free Stores
description: The Bond Store building once used to store goods is now the South Australian Maritime Museum.

title: Port Adelaide Council Chambers, St Vincent Street
description: 17 March 1956 Mayor PW Wicker launched centenary celebrations for Port Adelaide Council from its office balcony.

title: Divett Street
description: The Port’s dirt roads and low lying ground gave rise to two nick-names depending on the weather—Mudholia when wet, Dustholia when dry.

title: Missions to Seamen and Habor Lights
description: The Missions to Seamen offered sailors a bed, entertainment and religious support.

title: Jane Street
description: In the early days of the colony Jane Street was a community where teetotallers mixed with drinkers and smokers despite public debates about prohibition.

title: Harbors Board
description: The original Harbours Board building was completely demolished and replaced with a new building in the early twentieth century.

title: Queens Wharf
description: Queen's Wharf was one of the first two wharves built in Port Adelaide, providing the foundation of the Port we know today.

title: Port Dock Railway Station
description: The Port Dock Station opened in 1856. It was part of the first government built and owned railway in the British Empire.

title: Adelaide Observatory
description: The Adelaide Observatory complex was located in the West Parklands between the ends of Currie Street and Waymouth Street.

title: Maralinga
description: The main site for joint Australian–British nuclear weapons tests in Australia lies 800 kilometres north-west of Adelaide on the southern edge of the Great Victoria Desert.

title: Adelaide
description: The city of Adelaide refers here to the area within the outer boundary of the parklands; that is, the ‘square mile’ of the commercial centre, plus North Adelaide, the city’s first suburb.

title: St Luke's Church
description: St Luke's Church has a long history of supporting, and support from, the community of Adelaide.

title: Pirie Street Methodist Church
description: Pirie Street Methodist Church was the ‘cathedral church’ of Methodism in Adelaide.

title: Sym Choon Shops
description: In 1925/26 Thomas Sym Choon bought his four children a shop each.

title: Crown and Anchor Hotel
description: The current hotspot for alternative and grunge music has a colourful criminal history

title: Adelaide Fruit and Produce Exchange
description: The striking facade from Adelaide’s private produce market in the north east corner of the city remains a city landmark, though the market itself no longer operates.

title: Tandanya
description: Originally built in 1921 as a power station and office for the Adelaide Electric Supply Company, today this beautiful building houses Tandanya, Adelaide’s Aboriginal Cultural Institution

title: Chalmers Church Free Church of Scotland
description: The second oldest remaining church in Adelaide, Scots Church is still in use today.

title: Anzac Arch
description: Anzac Arch was built as a monument of appreciation to the men who fought in the First World War.

title: Saint Patrick's Church
description: Saint Patrick's Church on Grote Street is one of several historically significant Catholic church buildings in the southwest corner of the Adelaide CBD. The original building was the first Catholic church in Adelaide.

title: 181 Sturt Street
description: 181 Sturt Street was the home of Mahomet Allum, an Afghani herbalist and healer. It was later the office for Romani International Australia and the Australian Romani School of Gypsy Culture and Language.

title: Hellenic Club
description: The Hellenic Club on Morphett Street is one of several social venues established by the Greek community in Adelaide.

title: Saint Mary's Dominican Convent and School
description: Saint Mary's Convent and School is one of several historically significant Catholic church buildings and religious community residences based on Franklin Street and West Terrace.

title: Church of Archangels Michael and Gabriel
description: The Church of Archangels Michael and Gabriel stands on the site of Adelaide's oldest Greek Orthodox Church and remains an important centre for Greek cultural and community life in the city.

title: Archbishop's House
description: Archbishop’s House, formerly known as Bishop’s Palace, was built in 1845 as the residence for the Roman Catholic Bishop of Adelaide, Francis Murphy.

title: The Prince Albert Hotel
description: The Prince Albert Hotel, built in 1852, was associated with the Dreyer family, who originally migrated from Germany. It operated as a family business between 1852 and 1976.

title: Sturt Street School
description: Sturt Street Primary School, built in 1883, was the local primary school for families living in the South West of the Adelaide CBD.

title: Adelaide Gaol
description: One of South Australia's earliest buildings and home to over 300 000 people from 1841 to 1988, Adelaide Gaol is one of Australia's longest operating prisons.

title: Dunmoochin
description: Dunmoochin, built around 1858, was the home of Irish emigrants John and Honora Griffin and their three children. It is an example of the many workers’ cottages built in the West End.

title: River Torrens
description: The River Torrens has dominated the development of Adelaide and its metropolis, often in subtle or little recognised ways

title: Railway Hotel (Port Adelaide)
description: The two-storey historic building located at 247 St.

title: Black Diamond Corner
description: A notorious Port Adelaide intersection for much of the twentieth century, Black Diamond Corner was 'patrolled' by a series of 'silent cops' that were later replaced by the Port's first traffic lights

title: Torrens Island internment camp
description: During the First World War hundreds of men - 'enemy aliens' - were interned on Torrens Island in the Port River estuary north-west of Adelaide.

title: Colonial Sugar Refinery, Glanville
description: The Colonial Sugar Refinery (CSR) complex was constructed in 1891 on the Glanville side of the Port River, immediatel

title: Weman Building
description: Once home to one of colonial Port Adelaide's highly regarded sail-making and ship's chandlery businesses, the Weman Building has been faithfully restored to its original appearance and is part of the South Australian Maritime Museum's Lipson Street complex.

title: Adelaide General Post Office
description: The classically styled freestone Adelaide General Post Office housed both the post and telegraph offices which connected South Australia with the world.

title: Hart's Mill Complex
description: An icon of Port Adelaide's waterfront and the former home of South Australia's longest continually operating flour mill, the Hart's Mill complex now hosts a variety of cultural events and community activities

title: Adelaide Town Hall
description: The classically inspired Adelaide Town Hall was opened in 1866 and accommodates council chambers and civic reception rooms. It remains a notable landmark in Adelaide today.

title: British Hotel (Port Adelaide)
description: Port Adelaide’s British Hotel is the longest continuously licensed hostelry in the Port, and also the only remaining pub on North Parade.

title: McLaren Wharf
description: Built between 1839 and 1840, McLaren Wharf was the first element of maritime infrastructure established at Port Adelaide.

title: Parklands
description: An ongoing source of enjoyment and controversy, the parklands are a unique and remarkably intact feature of Adelaide

title: Glover Playground
description: The creation of playgrounds was a manifestation of moves for healthier environments for young children living in cities and suburbs

title: Central Market
description: The Central Market is a distinctively Adelaide institution, renowned for fine food and produce and a bustling cosmopolitan atmosphere

title: Adelaide City Baths
description: Adelaide’s City Baths were a prominent and important social institution for more than a century from their opening in 1861

title: Carclew
description: The youth arts centre Carclew was the starting point of McDouall Stuart’s expedition across Australia in 1861

title: Ayers House
description: Acquired and extended on the back of copper mining from the mid 1840s, Ayers House has had three main occupancies since the early twentieth century

title: Carrick Hill
description: An Elizabethan-style house from the 1930s with a large garden set in Adelaide’s foothills, Carrick Hill is now a museum and art gallery

title: Whitmore Square
description: Vibrant Whitmore Square continues to serve its diverse community in the southwest corner of Adelaide

title: Holy Trinity Church
description: Holy Trinity Church is the earliest surviving Anglican Church building in South Australia, and one of Adelaide’s oldest standing structures.

title: Rundle Street
description: Rundle Street has been a centre of shops and arcades, theatre and cafes, as well as acrimonious debate

title: Kangaroo Island
description: This island’s uniqueness is its major feature – there is nowhere else quite like it

title: St Francis Xavier Cathedral
description: The foundation stone for St Francis Xavier Cathedral was laid in 1856, and the construction of the tower completed in 1996.

title: Grenfell Street Power Station
description: Now home to Tandanya, this building opened in 1901 as the Grenfell Street Power Station Building.

title: Queen's Theatre
description: Built in 1840, the Queen's Theatre is the oldest surviving theatre building in Adelaide.

title: Grote Street
description: Her Majesty’s Theatre and the Central Market continue to attract people to Grote Street

title: Destitute Asylum
description: Relief for the poor, the pregnant and the unemployed was a theme from the colony’s commencement

title: Torrens Parade Ground and Training Depot
description: During both world wars the Parade Ground served as a mustering point and enlistment centre. The distinctive white building, known simply as the Torrens Training Depot, was built in 1936.

title: East Parklands
description: Despite an inauspicious start as a dumping ground for waste, the East Parklands gradually developed as an attractive centre for recreation in the city.

title: West Parklands
description: A temporary camping ground for the early European settlers, the West Parklands developed to host most notably a cemetery and a school.

title: The University of Adelaide
description: Reflecting the province's progressive founding ideals, the University of Adelaide on North Terrace was South Australia's first university, established in 1874.

title: Migration Museum
description: Opened in 1986 the Migration Museum in Adelaide was a world first.

title: Pirltawardli
description: Pirltawardli, (possum home) is the site of the first Christian mission to Aboriginal people in South Australia.

title: Adelaide Botanic Garden
description: The Adelaide Botanic Garden is a tranquil retreat within the city.

title: South Australian Museum
description: The South Australian Museum houses large scientific and cultural collections, with particular significance attached to its Aboriginal collection.

title: State Library of South Australia
description: The State Library of South Australia is one of several major cultural institutions located along North Terrace, on wh

title: Art Gallery of South Australia
description: The classical building of the Art Gallery of South Australia, with its gracious colonnaded portico, is one of the cultural landmarks on North Terrace.

title: Hindley Street
description: An eclectic mix since foundation, Hindley Street has seen it all

title: North Terrace East
description: North Terrace east is Adelaide’s premier cultural boulevard

title: Adelaide Brewery
description: Adelaide Brewery was an early colonial enterprise. While brewing has long ceased there, the building survives in a different guise.

title: Elder Park migrant hostel
description: Right in the centre of the city, Elder Park was a first stopping point for many new migrants arriving in South Australia.

title: East Terrace
description: A street in an area of contrasts - the rich, the poor, society figures, outcasts, business, leisure, health and education are associated with East Terrace

title: Elder Park
description: From dumping ground to pleasure gardens

title: Flinders Street
description: From ‘City of Churches’ to the ‘City of Cars’, Flinders Street reflects changes in Adelaide

title: Old Parliament House
description: The site of countless debates, Old Parliament House dates from 1855

title: North Terrace West
description: Stretching from Adelaide’s first survey point to Parliament House, the character of this part of North Terrace continues to evolve

title: Morphett Street
description: Morphett Street, named after prominent South Australian colonist Sir John Morphett, was a street in Colonel Light’s Plan of Adelaide in 1837 but in August 1967 it was extended to include Brown Street

title: Parliament House
description: The scene of pomp and ceremony, debates and demonstrations

title: Montefiore Hill
description: Montefiore Hill, overlooking the city planned by Colonel William Light, was named after South Australian Colonization Commissioner Jacob Montefiore

title: Pirie Street
description: Pirie Street has been home to cottages, churches, commerce and clubs

title: Mitchell Building
description: The 'University Building' has served many functions since it opened in 1882

title: King William Street
description: Celebration, commemoration and protest happen amid the grand buildings that line Adelaide's main thoroughfare

title: Elder Hall
description: The simple exterior of Elder Hall belies the richness of its interior and the resonance of its organ

title: Cheer-Up Hut
description: It started in a tent and grew – meals, clothes, accommodation and recreation for servicemen on the move.

title: South Terrace
description: Mansions at one end and cottages at the other, with businesses, welfare, medical and educational institutions in between, all overlooking the parklands

title: Institute Building
description: The oldest of North Terrace’s cultural buildings

title: West Terrace
description: A major cemetery, a palace and an observatory have graced West Terrace along with its parklands border

title: Brown Street
description: Brown Street, running from South Terrace to Grote Street, morphed into Morphett Street in 1967 but the area retains its out-of-the-way feel

title: Brookman Building
description: Developing technical education via a School of Mines and Industries leading to SAIT and then UniSA

title: Botanic Park
description: Botanic Park has blossomed as a place for informal family gatherings and a venue for public events

title: Government House
description: One of Adelaide’s oldest buildings, Government House welcomes thousands of visitors each year

title: Bonython Hall
description: Since 1936 this hall in Gothic style has served the University of Adelaide and the community

title: Exhibition Building and Grounds
description: Now lost, the Exhibition Building once dominated North Terrace

title: Adelaide Workmen's Homes
description: Cottages built for workers through a bequest from businessman and philanthropist Sir Thomas Elder

title: Adelaide Workmen's Homes
description: Cottages built for workers through a bequest from businessman and philanthropist Sir Thomas Elder

title: Adelaide Mosque
description: For over a century the Adelaide Mosque has provided a centre for prayer, community and celebration.

title: Fountain - Brookman Building
description: This fountain is outside the University of SA Brookman Building.

title: A Day Out
description: Pigs and people in Rundle Mall

title: Fountain - Art Gallery of South Australia
description: The Art Gallery of South Australia is one of several major cultural institutions that line North Terace between Kintore Avenue and Frome Road.

title: 14 Pieces Fountain - South Australian Museum
description: 14 Pieces is a sculpture fountain based on the opalised fossilised vertebrae of the Ichthyosaur in the South Australian Museum.

title: Bill's Fountain - State Library of South Australia
description: This fountain is a memorial to William Faulding Scammell, AO, CBE who was Chancellor of Adelaide University from 1991 to 1998.

title: War Memorial Fountain
description: South Australia became the first state in Australia to build a memorial for the First World War.

title: Susan Grace Benny Plaque
description: The first female local government councillor in Australia, Benny was a Justice of the Peace, a businesswoman and a lobbyist for women’s equality.

title: Fish for the Slate Pool Walkway
description: Within Catherine Truman’s work, Fish for the Slate Pool Walkway, the tentative nature of life is captured brilliantly from the depths of Truman’s imagination.

title: Robinson Bridge
description: Robinson’s swing bridge opened at Dock 1 in October 1886.

title: Torrens Lake Fountain
description: The Torrens Lake Fountain commemorates the first time South Australia was visited by a reigning monarch, Queen Elizabeth II in 1954.

title: J Reedman Memorial Drinking Fountain
description: The J Reedman Memorial Drinking Fountain was erected in Creswell Gardens on 7 September 1929. It is made of Angaston marble and signifies the achievements of John Cole Reedman, an Australian sports legend.

title: Farnese Hercules
description: One of three statues given to Adelaide by WA Horn, Hercules was unveiled in October 1892 in Victoria Square.

title: Sir Ross Smith Memorial
description: The Sir Ross Smith Memorial commemorates the achievements of aviator Sir Ross Smith and the first flight from England to Australia.

title: JH & GF Angas Memorial
description: The Angas Memorial was completed in 1915 as a tribute to the memory of George Fife Angas and John Howard Angas, colonists who contributed to the foundation of South Australia.

title: Bent Street Mural
description: Tony Rosella and Ash Rundle's environmentally and historically inspired artwork on the South Australian Police Building on Grenfell Street.

title: 'Street Art Poetry Project' Location 3
description: Mark Niehus' four-part series cemented his status as a prominent poet and artist in Adelaide.

title: Owen Broughton Sculpture
description: This Owen Broughton work won the 1976 Rundle Mall sculpture contest alongside Bert Flugelman's Mall's Balls

title: 'The Apron' by Karen Genoff
description: The Minister for Housing & Urban Development commissionned this work by Karen Genoff, an Adelaide local.

title: Mike Maka Mural
description: Mike Maka’s mural features a tired rhinocerous carrying the city of Adelaide on its back.

title: Rundle Lantern
description: The Rundle Lantern is 100% green-powered and the light show is carbon neutral.

title: J150 Plaque, Joachim Matthias Wendt
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Mary Jane Warnes
description: Deeply affected by the isolation and loneliness of her early married life, Mary Jane Warnes strived to improve conditions for her fellow countrywomen by founding the South Australian Country Women’s Association.

title: J150 Plaque, Norman Tindale
description: Norman Tindale was a prodigious anthropologist and polymath who chronicled Aboriginal culture, studied butterflies and moths, and broke Japanese wartime codes.

title: J150 Plaque, 'Padre' Arthur Thomas Strange
description: Kind-hearted and single-minded, 'Padre' Arthur Strange was the founder of the Helping Hand Centre.

title: J150 Plaque, David Shearer
description: Though a manufacturer of agricultural machinery, David Shearer also designed an early car, constructed an observatory, and was a keen artist.

title: J150 Plaque, Ronald Max'y Sharpe
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, James Arthur Prescott
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Eldred Norman
description: A racing car designer and driver, Eldred Norman was interested in all things mechanical.

title: J150 Plaque, William Muirden
description: William Muirden founded the Muirden College for Business Training, and was known for his well-balanced and harmonious nature.

title: J150 Plaque, Peter Nelson and Marjorie Jackson Nelson
description: A resolute cyclist, Peter Nelson was married to Marjorie Jackson Nelson and died of leukaemia at a young age. A phenomenally successful athlete in her own right, Marjorie Jackson Nelson went on to become a governor of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, May Mills
description: Educationist and sports administrator May Mills believed 'the wholesome development of a nation' depended on sport.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir John Melrose
description: Despite going blind, pastoralist and philanthropist Sir John Melrose continued to work with stock and managed properties.

title: J150 Plaque, John Abel McPherson
description: A union official and social reformer who was not a socialist, John McPherson became the first leader of South Australia's Parliamentary Labor Party.

title: J150 Plaque, Murdoch Stanley McLeod
description: A very industrious and conservative businessman, Murdoch McLeod was generous but modest and never flamboyant.

title: J150 Plaque, Percy Raymond Begg
description: Literally born in a tent, Percy Begg became a pioneer orthodontist whose innovations benefit patients to this day.

title: J150 Plaque, Dame Ruby Litchfield
description: Befitting a dedicated community worker and charity organizer, Dame Ruby Litchfield’s simple philosophy was ‘To live and let live’.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir William Mitchell
description: Philosopher, Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, and a teacher of economics, psychology and literature, Sir William Mitchell was nothing if not a polymath.

title: Birkenhead Bridge
description: Opened in 1940 as a replacement for the original Jervois Bridge, the Birkenhead Bridge was the first to employ a double-bascule design in Australia, and continues to function as a critical link between Port Adelaide and Lefevre Peninsula.

title: Jervois Bridge
description: For over half a century Port Adelaide’s Jervois Bridge was the only link by which pedestrians and wheeled vehicles could transit between the Port and Lefevre Peninsula.

title: J150 Plaque, Julian Edmund Tenison Woods
description: Julian Woods was the co-founder of the Sisters of St. Joseph, and a creative priest, educationist and scientist.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Kenneth Wills
description: Businessman and soldier Sir Kenneth Wills was Controller of the Allied Intelligence Bureau during the Second World War.

title: J150 Plaque, Lawrence Allen Wells
description: Explorer and surveyor Lawrence Wells survived gruelling expeditions but died after being struck by a railcar.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Samuel Way
description: A Chief Justice of South Australia, Sir Samuel Way was polished, cultured and proud.

title: J150 Plaque, Adelaide Laetitia Miethke
description: Prussian by descent, Adelaide Miethke was an educationist, and her School of the Air ‘bridged the lonely distance’ for outback children.

title: J150 Plaque, George Elton Mayo
description: George Elton Mayo was an extraordinarily versatile pioneer in human relations, management studies and psychoanalysis.

title: J150 Plaque, Cecil Thomas Madigan
description: A geologist and explorer, Cecil Madigan crossed the Simpson Desert in the last classic Australian exploration adventure.

title: J150 Plaque, Peter Waite
description: A pastoralist who built an empire on sheep and cattle runs, Peter Waite was also a major philanthropist.

title: J150 Plaque, William Charles Douglas Veale
description: Soldier, engineer and Adelaide Town Clerk William Veale is celebrated for revitalising the city's parklands.

title: J150 Plaque, David Unaipon
description: David Unaipon was an Aboriginal leader, writer, gatherer of legends, and inventor who was referred to in the press as 'the Black Leonardo'.

title: J150 Plaque, Alfred Hermann Traeger
description: Alf Traeger was friendly but self-effacing, and is perhaps best known as the inventor of the pedal wireless.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Robert Richard Torrens
description: Land titles reformer Sir Robert Richard Torrens reformed, amended and even radicalised the land trade system.

title: J150 Plaque, Alexander Tolmer
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Doris Taylor
description: Doris Taylor was the founder and organizer of Meals on Wheels, despite spending most of her life in a wheelchair.

title: J150 Plaque, Thomas Quinton Stow
description: Founder of the Congregational Church in South Australia, Thomas Stow was a strenuous minister and a dedicated opponent of state aid to religion.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edward Stirling
description: Sir Edward Stirling was (among other things) a surgeon, scientist, educationist, curator, lecturer and parliamentarian; in short, a Renaissance Man.

title: J150 Plaque, Tom Elder Barr Smith
description: A proverbial chip off the old block, Tom Elder Barr Smith was an astute businessman and generous philanthropist.

title: J150 Plaque, Robert Barr Smith
description: Robert Barr Smith had a genius for business. He was also a generous philanthropist, though his modesty dictated that much of the funding was dispensed anonymously.

title: J150 Plaque, Richard Bowyer Smith
description: Richard Bowyer Smith and his brother Clarence could both rightfully claim distinction as the inventors of the stump-jump plough.

title: J150 Plaque, Alfred Muller Simpson
description: Not content with being the nation’s biggest metal goods manufacturer, Alfred Muller Simpson was prominent in public life too.

title: J150 Plaque, Augustus Short
description: The energetic Augustus Short, South Australia’s first Anglican bishop, laid firm foundations for the growth of the Anglican Church in the new colony.

title: J150 Plaque, Richard Moritz Schomburgk
description: A botanist, horticulturist and the director of the Adelaide Botanic Garden, Richard Schomburgk was honoured locally as 'the people’s pet'.

title: J150 Plaque, Luther Robert Scammell
description: Manufacturing chemist Luther Scammell prepared compounds, saved a struggling business, and coined the name ‘Solyptol’.

title: J150 Plaque, John Ridley
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Victor York Richardson
description: The term 'all-round sportsman' might have been coined for Victor York Richardson, who excelled at cricket, football, baseball, lacrosse, tennis and basketball.

title: J150 Plaque, Arnold Edwin Victor Richardson
description: 1986 marked the 150th anniversary of the colonisation of South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, William Richard Randell
description: William Randell was a pioneer of River Murray paddle-steamers, and was responsible for both designing and piloting them.

title: J150 Plaque, Alexander Maurice Ramsay
description: As general manager of the South Australian Housing Trust, Alexander Maurice Ramsay was energetic and compassionate.

title: J150 Plaque, Tom Price
description: As the first Labor premier of South Australia, Tom Price established a minimum wage and electrified the tramways.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Archibald Grenfell Price
description: Working with this vivacious geographer, historian and educationist was said to be ‘like hanging on the tail of a comet’.

title: J150 Plaque, Margaret Preston
description: A highly influential painter and printmaker, Margaret Preston was once described as ‘a natural enemy of the dull’.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Thomas Playford
description: Premier for 26 years, Sir Thomas Playford managed the industrialisation of South Australia while maintaining a conservative social agenda.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Mark Oliphant
description: Best known as a governor of South Australia, Sir Mark Oliphant was also a pioneering nuclear physicist who became an outspoken anti-nuclear campaigner.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Henry Newland
description: Sir Henry Newland gained an international reputation as a pioneer plastic surgeon.

title: J150 Plaque, Paris Nesbit
description: Barrister, intellectual and proud hedonist, Paris Nesbit was an early starter who allegedly read Milton at three and translated Goethe at ten.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Mellis Napier
description: Sir Mellis Napier was a Chief Justice of South Australia, and arguably a reactionary one.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Pearcy Mountford
description: Charles Mountford was an anthropologist, writer and photographer, and was dedicated to the promotion of Aboriginal art and mythology.

title: J150 Plaque, William Mortlock
description: William Mortlock was a pastoralist and a generous and popular, if not necessarily brilliant, parliamentarian.

title: J150 Plaque, Daniel Moriarty
description: Daniel Moriarty has been acclaimed as the greatest footballer between the two World Wars.

title: J150 Plaque, Dame Roma Mitchell
description: A trailblazing jurist, Dame Roma Mitchell pushed for numerous law reforms and became South Australia’s first female governor.

title: J150 Plaque, Helen Mary Mayo
description: Medical practitioner Helen Mayo combined energy and a strong social conscience in her promotion of child health services.

title: J150 Plaque, Frederick May
description: Frederick May was an engineer and manufacturer, and the archetypal 'quiet achiever' who missed out on major fame and success.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Douglas Mawson
description: Sir Douglas Mawson became famous as an Antarctic explorer, but the geology of South Australia was his life’s work.

title: J150 Plaque, James Martin
description: A man of many parts, James Martin was an inventor, politician, philanthropist, engineer and ‘The Father of Gawler’.

title: J150 Plaque, Mary Helen MacKillop
description: An educationist and co-founder of the Sisters of St. Joseph, Mary MacKillop is now famous as Australia’s only Catholic saint.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edward Hayward
description: Known as ‘Bill’, Sir Edward Hayward was a businessman, patron of the arts and the originator of the Adelaide Christmas pageant.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Walter Crocker
description: A true internationalist, Sir Walter Crocker was a diplomat and Australian ambassador to many countries, a writer, and a centenarian.

title: J150 Plaque, Kate Cocks
description: Kate Cocks was both a welfare worker and the first woman police constable in the British Empire.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir John Cleland
description: Pathologist, naturalist and ardent conservationist, Professor Cleland, as he preferred to be known, contributed across many fields.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Robert Chapman
description: Sir Robert Chapman was an engineer with a gift for recognising the fundamentals of any problem.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Witto-Witto Cawthorne
description: Cawthorne was a dynamic music seller and concert manager, and is remembered as a genial raconteur.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Hugh Cairns
description: A pioneering neurosurgeon, Cairns worked extensively in the field of head injuries and was one of the first to promote the use of crash helmets for motor cyclists.

title: J150 Plaque, Henry John 'Harry' Butler
description: Harry Butler was a charismatic young aviator with a barnstorming style.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir George Brookman
description: A wealthy businessman and quiet philanthropist, Sir George Brookman was a conservative who was described as ‘hard but fair’ by one of his descendants.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Langdon Bonython
description: Sir Langdon Bonython was a progressive liberal whose long life encompassed being a parliamentarian, newspaper proprietor and philanthropist.

title: J150 Plaque,Lady Jean Bonython
description: Lady Bonython grew from ‘Baby Mayoress’ into a community worker and supporter of numerous charities, especially those benefiting women and children.

title: J150 Plaque, Abraham Tobias Boas
description: Abraham Tobias Boas was the first rabbi in South Australia, but so inclusive he was also called ‘the best Christian in Adelaide’.

title: J150 Plaque, John McConnell Black
description: Remembered as an eminent botanist, Black was also an accomplished linguist, who reprimanded his grandchildren in French and his dog in Spanish.

title: J150 Plaque, John Bishop
description: Instigator and first Artistic Director of the Adelaide Festival, John Bishop was a musician, teacher and visionary.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Richard Baker
description: An influential conservative politician and a supporter of Federation, Sir Richard Baker was the first President of the Senate.

title: J150 Plaque, John Stokes Bagshaw
description: ‘If worth doing, do it well’ was the motto of John Bagshaw, pioneering designer and manufacturer of agricultural machinery.

title: J150 Plaque, Walter Hervey Bagot
description: Bagot was an architect whose work, including Bonython Hall and the Barr Smith Library, displays his preference for classical and traditional designs.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Henry Ayers
description: A businessman, banker and parliamentarian, Henry Ayers was astute, hard-headed and politically adroit.

title: J150 Plaque, George French Angas
description: Equal parts naturalist and artist, George French Angas depicted the South Australian landscape, Aboriginal inhabitants, and flora and fauna with meticulous accuracy.

title: J150 Plaque, George Fife Angas
description: This merchant, banker, landowner and philanthropist was generous but shrewd, and often tagged with the phrase ‘philanthropy plus ten per cent’.

title: Dame Roma Mitchell Statue
description: Dame Roma Mitchell is depicted surrounded by her books looking relaxed and at home on North Terrace.

title: Pioneer Women's Memorial
description: The Pioneer Women's Memorial in the Garden of Remembrance is a tribute to the pioneer women of South Australia.

title: Port Adelaide Lighthouse
description: Installed in the 1860s as Port Adelaide's first fixed navigational beacon, and later used at South Neptune Island, the Port Adelaide Lighthouse today functions as an iconic museum display in the heart of the Port.

title: Steam Tug Yelta
description: Once an integral component of Port Adelaide's fleet of working vessels, this sole-surviving example of an operational South Australian steam tug has been faithfully restored and now promotes the Port's maritime heritage

title: Cross of Sacrifice
description: The Cross of Sacrifice, part of the Women's War Memorial, was funded completely by donation from 'the women of South Australia'

title: Archie Badenoch
description: Not many historic vessels in the care of maritime museums around the world still work as hard as South Australia’s ex-police launch, Archie Badenoch.

title: Barque South Australian
description: A former mail transport and Royal Navy vessel, the barque South Australian was integral to the early colonisation of South Australia...and became the colony's first documented shipwreck.

title: Sir Mark Oliphant bust
description: The bust of Sir Mark Oliphant on North Terrace honours an eminent scientist and the state’s first South Australian-born governor.

title: John Jefferson Bray Memorial Fountain
description: The John Jefferson Bray Memorial Fountain commemorates the life of a senior judge, scholar and poet

title: Sir Lawrence Bragg bust
description: The bust of Sir Lawrence Bragg commemorates a South Australian Nobel Laureate

title: Simpson and his Donkey
description: The iconic figure of of 'Simpson and his Donkey' looks over War Memorial Drive from the Angas Garden.

title: HMCS Protector
description: Built between 1882 and 1884, South Australia's only colonial warship was a veteran of three major conflicts and still exists today as a breakwater at Heron Island on the Great Barrier Reef

title: J150 Plaque, Harold Eustace Hill Ling
description: Harold Eustace Hill Ling was a joint patent-holder of that indisputable Australian icon, the Hills Hoist, and was responsible for expanding and diversifying Hills Industries Limited.

title: J150 Plaque, Essington Lewis
description: Essington Lewis was a hard-working industrialist who substantially developed and expanded B.H.P., and was Director-General of Munitions during the Second World War.

title: J150 Plaque, Andrew Alexander Kirkpatrick
description: A union leader, parliamentarian and egalitarian, Andrew Alexander Kirkpatrick pushed for equal rights for women.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Sidney Kidman
description: Abstemious but easy-going, Sir Sidney Kidman was a pastoralist and philanthropist who made friends easily.

title: J150 Plaque, August Kavel
description: An austere but tolerant Lutheran migrant leader, August Kavel contributed significantly to South Australia’s rich legacy of German culture.

title: J150 Plaque, Hooper Josse Brewster Jones
description: The music of unconventional musician and composer Hooper Josse Brewster Jones was as distinctive as his name.

title: J150 Plaque, Norman William Jolly
description: A forestry scientist by profession, Norman Jolly was also an accomplished scholar known for his integrity and keen critical faculty.

title: J150 Plaque, Jimmy James
description: A masterly Aboriginal police tracker, Jimmy James saved lives, gathered evidence and attained legendary status.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Roland Jacobs
description: Sir Roland Jacobs was a shrewd businessman, but also a warm and generous philanthropist with no interest in personal wealth.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Walter Watson Hughes
description: A pastoralist and mine-owner once accused of fraud, Hughes stated shortly before his death: ‘I have been a sinner all my life’.

title: J150 Plaque, Amos William Howard
description: Howard was a nurseryman and great promoter of subterranean clover. His discoveries have benefited farmers’ pastures throughout South Australia.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Edward Holden
description: Motor car manufacturer and industrialist Sir Edward Holden gave his name to a car, albeit posthumously.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Hans Heysen
description: Sir Hans Heysen was a masterly artist, the immortaliser of the gum tree on canvas, and a dedicated conservationist.

title: J150 Plaque, Sir Robert Helpmann
description: His versatility as actor, dancer, producer and choreographer, coupled with flamboyance and wit, made Sir Robert Helpmann a household name.

title: J150 Plaque, Colin Sidney Hayes
description: Colin Sidney Hayes is remembered as possibly the greatest racehorse trainer and thoroughbred breeder in the history of Australian racing.

title: J150 Plaque, Charles Allan Seymour Hawker
